JP11:17am

Predicting the daily swing in oil prices is proving to be one of the main challenges in markets at the moment. Indeed one day after Brent dipped -3.72% and to a five-month low, it recovered much of these losses in a single swing yesterday after bouncing back +2.37%. The catalyst was the attacks on tankers in the Gulf of Oman, the second attack in a month near the Strait of Hormuz chokepoint, which has led to fears that accelerated hostilities in the region are to return. The US Secretary of State blamed Iran for the attacks, in comments that President Trump subsequently retweeted, and overnight the US released a video demonstrating Iran’s involvement, saying an Iranian boat removed an unexploded mine from a US ship. US officials also suggested that a military response has not been ruled out. Separately, data from the US Energy Information Administration showed that in March, the US imported the lowest amount of crude oil from OPEC countries since March 1986, continuing a decade-long trend of lower US crude oil imports from the OPEC countries.

Here's Morgan Stanley:

JP11:28am

(@Excel Developer Wink smile)

Viking1 Any comment on FT article “ record overseas investments in UK smaller companies This is just the start ?
JP11:29am

May 2019 sales up +3.2% at group level, and -1.7% ex China, despite X3: BMW
group reported May sales at 210k units, up 6.5k units or by +3.2% YoY, with
BMW brand sales up 4.6% YoY while MINI was down 5.1%. X3 remained solid, up
88.4% yoy (+13k units), X4 grew 92.5% in May (+2.6k units). Disappointingly, the 5
series has faded sharply, after showing a strong performance in most of 2018,
with sales falling every month starting Nov'18 – they fell 6.7% in May; and most
other model series witnessed sharp or even double-digit declines – especially the
Sedans. However, SUV mix is improving each month, primarily due to the new X3
(with China localisation) and growing sales in X2 and X4 now.

red global slowdown dosnt bode well for bmw so it can go from $hit to worse. cheap can get cheaper. the main reason for avoiding it now.
11:28 am
JP11:29am

Europe remained negative at -5.4%, with weak sales in top 5 European region ex
Germany, where sales were strong at +30.3% – at a time when the overall
German market grew 3.9% (days adjusted); while France was down 4.4%, Italy
down 7.4% and UK was the weakest at -8.0%. The US was down again at -3.1%.
China continued to remain the growth driver, up 32.8%, with local JV growth at
26% due to the new X3 production, and imports bounced to +58%, supported by
tariff suspension. Both the German and China import growth numbers suggest
some re-stocking or special deals to generate that growth. BMW's 12m rolling
sales are now slowly growing, were +0.8% in May, and have remained flat for
last 3 months in a row – with all the new SUV products.

JP11:29am

Model cycles drive investor confidence, but 12m rolling sales growth is down to
just 0.8%: On an analytical level, we agree that BMW's model cycle has
improved, and should improve (a little) further in FY19, with all SUVs now
replaced, and adding the new X7 and 8-series as well at the high end. However,
the net benefit to earnings has been minimal – and now the X1 and 5-series sales
have started declining vs tough comps, and X3 comps starts to get tougher in 2H.
Given limited growth seen from the 7-series and 5-series replacements, we worry
about the potential success of the 3-series sedan replacement, in a segment that
is clearly declining. Given this backdrop of limited global volume growth, slowing
China, tariff worries, how will BMW change its margin trend and capex spend,
meet CO2 targets, and address product mix pressure?

red u could pair it with something else in sector as u suspect it will be an outperformer in what may be an underperforming sector
JP11:30am

Conclusion: BMW is cheap, but needs change to recover margins and provide a
catalyst: BMW has underperformed YTD as higher beta names have performed better, but also because investors are (rightly) worried about FY19 guidance – for
EBIT margins and FCF. We believe BMW will need to take more steps to reduce
costs and prioritize its focus on margin and FCF improvements, as well as
formulating a credible long-term CO2 strategy. BMW's plans to reduce
complexity and lead times, and reduce spending by €12bn could be exactly what
BMW needs, if it can achieve them. We have BMW trading on just 6.9x FY19e P/E,
1.0x EV/EBITDA, and 12% EV/sales (if industrial net cash matters) and we think
further change could be a catalyst to drive it closer to our €75 PT. We prefer
Daimler and Michelin especially of our Overweight ratings. BMW remains Equalweight.

11:36 am
JP11:37am

GERMAN OEM VALUATIONS WOULD LIKELY RE-RATE IF TESLA FAILS
Tesla's rise has put huge pressure on the valuations of traditional OEMs. Tesla's initial success suggested that barriers to entry
in the auto industry were lower than assumed. Its technology seemed ahead of all other OEMs - damaging the Germans'
reputation for innovation and leadership. Tesla has taken market share from the German OEMs in the US, UK and some other
regions. And Tesla's impressive long-range EVs – and significant sales volumes – encouraged regulators to intensify their
demands. In simple terms, Tesla has cost the Germans a significant amount of market cap.

PBateman @flan wish they'd keep that for chinese models then!
Flaneur China is just a 1980s Essex reboot ;)
JP11:38am

The traditional OEMs have de-rated to extremely low levels, despite strong margins and cashflows (albeit declining ones). What
exactly is the market trying to tell us? Clearly it thinks the big auto companies are about to implode. For sure, everyone is worried
about the costs and consequences of electrification and autonomy. The sector also faces a number of nasty issues from diesel
to tariffs. But is that enough to explain companies trading on such low multiples and substantial FCF yields?
Tesla still has a market cap of over USD$30bn, which seems wild. Tesla made less than 250,000 units in 2018, with its original
S/X model volumes stalling, high-end Model 3 demand in the US and Canada apparently fulfilled and international demand
uncertain. Its technological edge has gone -the big OEMs have now demonstrated that they can build long range electric cars
with ADAS too. Yet while one part of the market hates German auto companies because of fears that loss-making electric cars
may slightly lower margins, another part bids up Tesla that only sells loss-making electric cars.
Back on the European continent, we find huge valuations of Ferrari – a small producer dependent on combustion engines –
these are central to its products and the very essence of the brand. Ferrari's margins are great but it makes only about 9,000
cars a year and generated only €400mn of cash. Yet Ferrari now has an Enterprise Value that’s higher than BMW’s, which sells
2.5 million cars per year, with nearly €100bn of revenues and that in 2018 generated Industrial free cash of €2.7bn. While one
part of the market hates German companies that make combustion engines, another part loves this Italian company that only
makes combustion engines. There seems very little logic and coherence when we look at the relative values of Tesla, Ferrari,
Aston Martin and traditional OEMs like VW, BMW and DAI.

Excel Developer "The sector also faces a number of nasty issues from dieselto tariffs. But is that enough to explain companies trading on such low multiples and substantial FCF yields?" thought so

Some clamor for tech related stuff....in case you missed it Broadcom put out a warning yesterday -- revenue outlook down by c. $2bn for next two quarters.

11:46 am
JP11:46am

Neil Campling at Mirabaud here -- forgive the typos:

JP11:46am

Broadcom warning: stock -8% ah and taking skyworks -3% and qorvo -2%. Fy revenues cut by $2b v prior guide of $24.5b. Just reported q2 which revs missed consensus by $160m so we are clearly legging lower in h2. Its demand related and they point to both huawei and the geopolitical tensions. Core semis fell -7% qoq and -10% yoy. But it’s a broad based decline they are now predicting. On the call the ceo is making clear that the uncertainty is extending (beyond huawei). The huawei business was worth $900m, so even if you are adjusting that to worst cast scenario of zero. There is a further $1b of revenues ‘missing’ in the h2. Street has $12.8b for h2, so stripping out huawei you still have about an 8% of h2 sales that have disappeared.

JP11:47am

Peel Hunt seem to think Broadcom are factoring trade war escalation:

11:47 am
JP11:47am

Broadcom, one of the largest semi companies in the world, has reduced its revenue outlook by c.$2bn for the next two quarters. Huawei, for Broadcom, was worth around $900m last year. The $2bn downgrade for the next two quarters therefore accounts for broader demand dynamics. The company is trying, we think, to accommodate the possibility of the next round of tariffs coming into place (c$300bn) in the US-China trade-war.
